unnormalised: ## Automotive: New Traffic Regulations Aim to Curb Chaos, Educate Drivers
normalised: ## Automotive: New Traffic Regulations Aim to Curb Chaos, Educate Drivers

unnormalised: New Delhi, India – Stricter traffic regulations are being rolled out across major Indian cities starting November 15th, aiming to improve road safety and reduce accidents. These regulations, informed by studies from IIT Delhi's Transportation Research and Injury Prevention Programme, focus on stricter enforcement of existing rules and public awareness campaigns.
normalised: New Delhi, India – Stricter traffic regulations are being rolled out across major Indian cities starting november fifteenth, aiming to improve road safety and reduce accidents. These regulations, informed by studies from I I T Delhi's Transportation Research and Injury Prevention Programme, focus on stricter enforcement of existing rules and public awareness campaigns.

unnormalised: Key changes include increased fines for offenses like signal jumping (Rs. 5000) and driving without a helmet (Rs. 2000), alongside a zero-tolerance policy for drunk driving. Mandatory refresher courses are also being introduced for repeat offenders, drawing parallels to the traffic school scene in the iconic Bollywood film "3 Idiots," though with a significantly less comical and more rehabilitative approach.
normalised: Key changes include increased fines for offenses like signal jumping (rupees five thousand) and driving without a helmet (rupees two thousand), alongside a zero-tolerance policy for drunk driving. Mandatory refresher courses are also being introduced for repeat offenders, drawing parallels to the traffic school scene in the iconic Bollywood film "three Idiots," though with a significantly less comical and more rehabilitative approach.

unnormalised: The government also plans to implement a point-based system, where accumulation of points for traffic violations can lead to suspension or revocation of driving licenses. Experts hope these measures, coupled with improved road infrastructure, will lead to a significant reduction in traffic congestion and accidents on Indian roads. Moreover, new rules also mandate rear seatbelt usage and penalize non-compliance with a fine of Rs. 1000. Speed limits are also being revised on some expressways; for example, the Mumbai-Pune expressway has a revised speed limit of 100 km/hr for cars.
